metadata.case_name: Mithoolal Nayak v. Life Insurance Corporation of India

facts.text: Mahajan Deolal, resident of village Singhpur, Tehsil Narsinghpur, small landholder, submitted first proposal for life insurance of Rs. 10,000/- through agent Rahatullah Khan in December 1942, age stated as 45, referee Motilal Nayak (brother of appellant, doctor).

Mahajan Deolal examined by Dr. D.D. Desai in 1942; submitted two reports, confidential one stating anaemic, age ~55, dilated heart, right lung old pneumonia/pleurisy, general health run down, total physical wreck, uninsurable.
First proposal lapsed after 6 months without further exams by Civil Surgeon Hoshangabad and DMO Railways Jabalpur as directed; Rs. 571/- paid towards first premium.

Mahajan Deolal treated by Dr. P.N. Lakshmanan (Consulting Physician, Jabalpur) from Sept 7 to Oct 6, 1943 for anaemia, oedema of feet, diarrhoea, panting on exertion, secondary anaemia due to iron deficiency/malnutrition, cardiac asthma, dilatation of heart; brought by Dr. Motilal Nayak.

Second proposal for Rs. 25,000/- on July 16, 1944 through same agent; personal statement claimed earlier proposal pending, answered 'No' to consulting medical man in past 5 years (Q13), last treatment (Q12b), shortness of breath, anaemia, asthma (Q5a,5b etc.); friend's report by Dr. Motilal Nayak stating good health, no illness known.
Examined by Dr. Kapadia (DMO Railways Jabalpur); reported healthy, age 52-54, history of pneumonia 4-5 years ago, cholera; recommended policy of 14 years.
Further declarations of good health Dec 29, 1944 and Feb 12, 1945; policy issued March 13, 1945 effective Jan 15, 1945 for Rs.25,000 payable Jan 15, 1968 or death; first premium from 1942 deposit.
Mahajan Deolal requested policy cancellation May 22, 1945 due to financial condition; policy lapsed after 1945 premium.
Policy assigned to appellant Mithoolal Nayak on Oct 18, 1945; registered by company Nov 1, 1945; appellant stated no insurable interest except friendship, purchased for Rs.427.12 np (premiums paid).
Revival request Oct 28, 1945; exams by Dr. Belapurkar and Dr. Clarke Feb 25, 1946; revived July 1946 after appellant paid arrears.
Mahajan Deolal died Nov 12, 1946; death certificate by Dr. Clarke: primary malaria + severe diarrhoea, secondary anaemia, chronic bronchitis, enlarged liver; mentioned Dr. Lakshmanan.
Appellant demanded Rs.26,000/-; repudiated Oct 10, 1947 for deliberate misstatements/fraudulent suppression in proposal/personal statement.

Suit filed by appellant against Oriental Govt. Security Life Assurance Co. Ltd.; decreed May 7, 1949 by Addl. Dist. Judge Jabalpur; appeal allowed Aug 28, 1956 by MP High Court, suit dismissed with costs; certificate under Art.133(1)(a).
LIC substituted Feb 16, 1960 by SC order post Life Insurance Corporation Act 1956.

legal_issues.text: Whether the policy was vitiated by fraudulent suppression of material facts by Mahajan Deolal?
Whether the present appellant had no insurable interest in the life of the insured, and if so, can he sue on the policy?
Whether the respondent company had issued the policy with full knowledge of the facts relating to the health of the insured and if so, is it estopped from contesting the validity of the policy?
Whether in any event the appellant is entitled to refund of the money he had paid to the respondent company?

petitioner_arguments.text: Answers in proposal/personal statement though not strictly accurate, not fraudulent suppression under s.45 Insurance Act 1938; ailments treated by Dr. Lakshmanan trivial/casual.
Company examined insured by 4 doctors (Desai, Kapadia, Belapurkar, Clarke), knew conflicting reports, full knowledge of health, estopped from repudiating; Explanation to s.19 Contract Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Explanation to s.19 Indian Contract Act; policy terms

petitioner_arguments.text: Assignment valid under s.38 Insurance Act; even if no insurable interest, policy valid at inception for insured's benefit.
Revival not new contract; s.45 period from original policy date.

respondent_arguments.text: Negative answers to Q13 proposal, Q12b,5a,5b etc. personal statement deliberately false; suppressed serious treatment by Dr. Lakshmanan 1943; fraudulent under s.45 Insurance Act.
Appellant no insurable interest, mere gamble on life; policy from inception for appellant's benefit via brother.
No full knowledge of 1943 treatment; exams did not reveal it; no estoppel/waiver.
No refund; policy terms forfeit moneys on fraud; no s.64/65 Contract Act; cannot recover on own fraud.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.17,64,65 Indian Contract Act; policy terms

court_reasoning.text: s.45 Insurance Act applies (policy post-Act, >2 years to repudiation); three conditions fulfilled: material suppression (serious anaemia etc. 1943 by Dr. Lakshmanan, not trivial), fraudulent, known false by insured.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Dr. Lakshmanan evidence clear; Dr. Motilal Nayak false friend's report despite taking insured; son minimised but fees/consult indicate serious.

court_reasoning.text: No waiver/estoppel; company unaware of 1943 treatment despite exams; insured concealed deliberately, cannot claim no difference if known; policy averments basis of contract.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Explanation s.19 inapplicable; fraud induced consent.

court_reasoning.text: Unnecessary to decide insurable interest as policy void ab initio due to insured's fraud; assignee no better position.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant out of court on i1.

court_reasoning.text: No refund; policy terms forfeit moneys on fraud; no s.64/65 Contract Act; courts won't aid fraud recovery.

holdings.text: Policy void under s.45 Insurance Act due to fraudulent suppression of material facts by insured.
No estoppel/waiver by company despite medical exams.
No refund of premiums to appellant.

statutes_cited.name: Insurance Act, 1938
statutes_cited.relevance: s.45 protects policy after 2 years unless fraud on material matter known to insured; s.38 validates assignments

statutes_cited.name: Indian Contract Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: s.17 defines fraud; s.19/Explanation on misrepresentation; s.30 voids wagering; s.64/65 no application to fraud/breach of warranty

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal to Supreme Court

statutes_cited.name: Life Insurance Corporation Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Statutory transfer of assets/liabilities to LIC

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding Madhya Pradesh High Court's reversal of trial court's decree; suit dismissed with costs as policy void for fraudulent suppression by insured; no refund to appellant.
outcome.costs: Suit dismissed with costs (as per High Court)

key_quotes.text: "the insurer shows that such statement was on a material matter or suppressed facts which it was material to disclose and that it was fraudulently made by the policy-holder"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key condition under s.45 Insurance Act for avoiding policy after 2 years

key_quotes.text: "Fraud, according to s. 17 of the Indian Contract Act... the suggestion, as to a fact, of that which is not true... the active concealment of a fact"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "A man who has so acted cannot afterwards turn round and say It could have made no difference if you had known the truth."
key_quotes.speaker: court
